metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: Compare sinusoidal AC voltages produced as a result of the uniform rotation of a loop in a constant magnetic field with reference to frequency, period, amplitude, peak-to-peak voltage (Vp–p) and peak-to-peak current (Ip–p)

sinusoidal_shape_origin.name: Origin of Sinusoidal Shape
sinusoidal_shape_origin.correct: The sinusoidal shape arises because the component of magnetic flux through the rotating loop varies as the sine of the rotation angle.

the magnetic field oscillates.error: The magnetic field is constant. The coil rotates.
the magnetic field oscillates.fix: A constant magnetic field + rotating coil = changing flux through the coil.
the magnetic field oscillates.action: The field stays fixed. What changes is the coil's orientation to the field.

the current reverses direction.error: Current reversal is a result, not the cause, of the sinusoidal shape.
the current reverses direction.fix: The shape comes from geometry: flux ∝ cos(θ), so EMF ∝ sin(θ).
the current reverses direction.action: Draw a coil at 0°, 45°, 90°. Calculate flux at each angle.

the slip rings produce alternating conta.error: Slip rings maintain continuous contact. They don't create alternation.
the slip rings produce alternating conta.fix: Slip rings allow current to flow out continuously. The EMF's sinusoidal variation comes from flux changes.
the slip rings produce alternating conta.action: Slip rings = continuous contact. Split ring commutator = reverses contact.

persistent.gap: You don't understand why AC is sinusoidal.
persistent.action: Trace the geometry: coil perpendicular to field → max flux, no flux change, zero EMF. Coil parallel → zero flux, max flux change, max EMF.

flux_emf_phase_relationship.name: Flux-EMF Phase Relationship
flux_emf_phase_relationship.correct: EMF is maximum when flux is changing most rapidly (coil parallel to field). EMF is zero when flux is at maximum or minimum (coil perpendicular to field).

EMF is maximum when flux is maximum.error: EMF depends on rate of CHANGE of flux, not flux value.
EMF is maximum when flux is maximum.fix: At max flux, flux is momentarily constant → rate of change = 0 → EMF = 0.
EMF is maximum when flux is maximum.action: Faraday's law: EMF = −NΔΦ/Δt. Max flux means Δ = 0 at that instant.

EMF and flux are always in phase.fix: EMF is the negative gradient of the flux-time graph. Max gradient occurs at zero flux.
EMF and flux are always in phase.action: Draw flux vs time (cosine). Draw its gradient (negative sine). Compare peaks.

EMF is zero when flux changes direction.error: EMF is zero when flux is at extremes, not when crossing zero.
EMF is zero when flux changes direction.fix: When flux = 0 (crossing zero), it's changing most rapidly → max EMF.
EMF is zero when flux changes direction.action: On the flux graph, steepest slope = zero crossing. That's max EMF.

persistent.gap: You're confusing flux value with rate of flux change.
persistent.action: Draw Φ vs t. At each point, find the gradient. That gradient is the EMF.

frequency_definition.name: AC Frequency
frequency_definition.correct: Frequency is the number of complete cycles per second, measured in Hertz (Hz). For a rotating coil, f equals the number of rotations per second.

the speed of electron flow.error: That's current, not frequency. Frequency is about repetition rate.
the speed of electron flow.fix: Frequency counts how many cycles happen in one second.
the speed of electron flow.action: Australian mains is 50 Hz = 50 complete cycles every second.

the maximum voltage reached.fix: Frequency describes how fast it oscillates. Amplitude describes how big.
the maximum voltage reached.action: Two waves can have same amplitude but different frequencies.

the time for one cycle.error: That's period, the inverse of frequency.
the time for one cycle.fix: Frequency = 1/period. Period is time per cycle; frequency is cycles per second.

persistent.gap: You're confusing frequency with other wave properties.
persistent.action: Make a table: property, symbol, unit, meaning. Include f, T, A, Vp, Vp-p.

period_definition.name: AC Period
period_definition.correct: Period is the time for one complete cycle, measured in seconds. For Australian mains at 50 Hz, the period is 0.02 s (20 ms).

the number of cycles per second.fix: Period is time per cycle. Frequency is cycles per time. They're inverses.
the number of cycles per second.action: T = 1/f and f = 1/T. Know both directions.

the time between peaks and troughs.fix: A full period is peak-to-peak through the same direction. Peak to trough is half.
the time between peaks and troughs.action: One period: start at +Vp, go through 0, -Vp, 0, back to +Vp.

always 1 second.error: Period depends on frequency. Only f = 1 Hz gives T = 1 s.
always 1 second.action: Calculate T for different frequencies: 50 Hz, 60 Hz, 100 Hz.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the frequency-period relationship.
persistent.action: Calculate: if f = 50 Hz, T = ?. If T = 0.01 s, f = ?. Practice conversions.

frequency_period_relationship.name: Frequency-Period Relationship
frequency_period_relationship.correct: Frequency and period are inversely proportional. Doubling frequency halves the period. If f = 50 Hz, T = 20 ms.

directly proportional.error: They are INVERSELY related, not directly.
directly proportional.fix: f = 1/T means increasing f decreases T.
directly proportional.action: Higher frequency = faster oscillation = shorter time per cycle.

f = T.error: They have different units and are reciprocals.
f = T.fix: f is measured in Hz (per second). T is measured in seconds.
f = T.action: Check units: if f = 50 Hz, T cannot also equal 50. It equals 0.02 s.

independent of each other.error: They are directly linked by f = 1/T.
independent of each other.fix: One determines the other. Know one, calculate the other.
independent of each other.action: If someone says f = 100 Hz and T = 0.02 s, catch the contradiction.

persistent.gap: You're not applying the inverse relationship.
persistent.action: Calculate five f→T and five T→f conversions until automatic.

amplitude_definition.name: Amplitude (Peak Value)
amplitude_definition.correct: Amplitude is the maximum displacement from zero, equal to the peak value (Vp). It represents the maximum voltage reached during each cycle.

the average voltage.error: Average AC voltage over a full cycle is zero.
the average voltage.fix: Amplitude is the maximum, not average. For the 'effective' average, use RMS.
the average voltage.action: On a sine wave, amplitude is the distance from center to peak, not center to average.

the peak-to-peak voltage.action: If amplitude is 325 V, Vp-p = 650 V.

the RMS voltage.error: RMS is smaller than amplitude by factor of √2.
the RMS voltage.fix: Vrms = Vp/√2 ≈ 0.707 × Vp. They're different values.
the RMS voltage.action: 230 V mains is Vrms. The amplitude (Vp) is actually 325 V.

persistent.gap: You're confusing amplitude with other voltage measures.
persistent.action: Draw a sine wave. Label Vp (amplitude), Vp-p (peak-to-peak), and mark where Vrms would sit.

peak_to_peak_voltage.name: Peak-to-Peak Voltage
peak_to_peak_voltage.correct: Peak-to-peak voltage is the total voltage swing from maximum positive to maximum negative. Vp-p = 2 × Vp.

equal to the amplitude.fix: Amplitude measures from zero to peak. Vp-p measures from +peak to −peak.
equal to the amplitude.action: From +325 V to −325 V is 650 V total swing.

Vp divided by 2.error: It's Vp times 2, not divided by 2.
Vp divided by 2.fix: Vp-p = 2Vp. The factor is multiplication, not division.
Vp divided by 2.action: If Vp = 100 V, Vp-p = 200 V, not 50 V.

the same as RMS voltage.error: RMS is much smaller than peak-to-peak.
the same as RMS voltage.fix: Vp-p = 2Vp while Vrms = Vp/√2. So Vp-p ≈ 2.83 × Vrms.
the same as RMS voltage.action: For 230 V RMS mains, Vp-p ≈ 650 V. Very different values.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly relating Vp and Vp-p.
persistent.action: Practice: given Vp, find Vp-p. Given Vp-p, find Vp. The factor is always 2.

peak_to_peak_current.name: Peak-to-Peak Current
peak_to_peak_current.correct: Peak-to-peak current follows the same relationship as voltage: Ip-p = 2 × Ip.

Ip-p = Ip.error: The peak-to-peak is double the peak.
Ip-p = Ip.fix: Current swings from +Ip to −Ip, a total change of 2Ip.

Ip-p = Vp-p/R.error: This would give RMS-related values, not peak-to-peak.
Ip-p = Vp-p/R.fix: Ip-p = 2Ip where Ip = Vp/R. So Ip-p = 2Vp/R.
Ip-p = Vp-p/R.action: Calculate step by step: Vp → Ip → Ip-p.

unrelated to Ip.fix: Just like Vp-p = 2Vp, we have Ip-p = 2Ip.
unrelated to Ip.action: Same factor of 2 applies to both voltage and current.

persistent.gap: You're not applying the peak-to-peak relationship to current.
persistent.action: Calculate Ip-p for several values of Ip. The relationship is always ×2.

rotation_frequency_link.name: Rotation Rate and AC Frequency
rotation_frequency_link.correct: The frequency of the AC output equals the rotation rate of the coil. One rotation produces one complete cycle of AC.

double the rotation rate.error: One rotation = one cycle. They're equal.
double the rotation rate.fix: Each rotation brings the coil through all orientations once → one full AC cycle.

half the rotation rate.fix: One rotation = one complete sine wave = one cycle = one Hz unit.
half the rotation rate.action: Track one rotation: 0° → 90° → 180° → 270° → 360° = one full cycle.

unrelated to rotation rate.fix: The physical rotation directly determines electrical frequency.
unrelated to rotation rate.action: To get 60 Hz, rotate the coil 60 times per second.

persistent.gap: You don't see the direct link between mechanical rotation and AC frequency.
persistent.action: Trace one full rotation through all coil orientations. Verify it produces one full cycle.

rotation_amplitude_link.name: Rotation Rate and Amplitude
rotation_amplitude_link.correct: Faster rotation increases the rate of flux change, producing larger peak EMF. Amplitude is directly proportional to rotation frequency.

amplitude stays constant.error: Faster rotation = faster flux change = larger EMF.
amplitude stays constant.fix: EMF = −NΔΦ/Δt. Smaller Δt (faster rotation) means larger EMF.
amplitude stays constant.action: Double the rotation speed → double the amplitude.

amplitude decreases with faster rotation.fix: Rate of change increases with speed. More change per second = more EMF.
amplitude decreases with faster rotation.action: Think of it: spinning the coil faster makes it cut through field lines faster.

amplitude depends only on coil size.error: Amplitude depends on coil size AND rotation speed AND field strength.
amplitude depends only on coil size.fix: Vp ∝ NABω. All factors matter: turns, area, field, rotation rate.
amplitude depends only on coil size.action: To increase Vp: more turns, bigger coil, stronger field, OR faster rotation.

persistent.gap: You don't understand what controls AC amplitude.
persistent.action: List all factors affecting Vp: N (turns), A (area), B (field), ω (rotation rate). All proportional.

reading_oscilloscope.name: Reading AC from Oscilloscope
reading_oscilloscope.correct: An oscilloscope displays voltage vs time. Peak-to-peak voltage is measured as the total vertical height of the trace. Period is read horizontally.

the trace shows current.error: Standard oscilloscopes display voltage, not current.
the trace shows current.fix: An oscilloscope shows voltage vs time. To measure current, use a resistor with known R.
the trace shows current.action: Oscilloscope y-axis = voltage. To find current: I = V/R.

vertical scale shows frequency.error: Vertical is voltage. Horizontal is time.
vertical scale shows frequency.fix: Read period from horizontal axis, then calculate f = 1/T.
vertical scale shows frequency.action: Time is always horizontal. Voltage is always vertical on an oscilloscope.

peak voltage equals trace height.error: Trace height is Vp-p, not Vp.
peak voltage equals trace height.fix: Trace goes from +Vp to −Vp. Total height = Vp-p = 2Vp.
peak voltage equals trace height.action: Measure full height, then divide by 2 to get Vp.

persistent.gap: You don't know how to read oscilloscope traces.
persistent.action: Practice: given a trace, extract Vp-p (height), T (horizontal repeat), then calculate Vp and f.

comparing_ac_sources.name: Comparing AC Voltage Sources
comparing_ac_sources.correct: AC sources are compared using frequency, period, amplitude (Vp), and peak-to-peak values. Higher frequency means shorter period and (for same generator) higher amplitude.

only compare RMS values.error: Peak and peak-to-peak values also matter for comparison.
only compare RMS values.fix: RMS gives effective power comparison. Peak values matter for component ratings.
only compare RMS values.action: A capacitor rated at 100 V can't handle 230 V RMS because Vp = 325 V.

frequency doesn't affect power.error: Higher frequency can mean higher amplitude, affecting power.
frequency doesn't affect power.fix: If rotation speed increases, both f and Vp increase, dramatically increasing power.
frequency doesn't affect power.action: Power ∝ V². If V doubles with f, power quadruples.

all 50 Hz AC sources are identical.error: Same frequency doesn't mean same amplitude.
all 50 Hz AC sources are identical.fix: Different generators can produce 50 Hz at different voltages.
all 50 Hz AC sources are identical.action: A 12 V car alternator and 230 V mains both operate at similar frequencies but very different voltages.

persistent.gap: You don't know how to systematically compare AC sources.
persistent.action: For any AC source, list: f, T, Vp, Vp-p, Ip, Ip-p. Then compare.

sinusoidal_generation.instructions: Apply your understanding of sinusoidal AC generation to practical scenarios.

frequency_period.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of frequency and period relationships.

comparing_ac.title: Complete AC Comparison
comparing_ac.instructions: Synthesise your understanding to compare AC sources comprehensively.

sentences.text: Two generators with identical coils but different rotation speeds will produce AC with different {{d1}} and different {{d2}}, demonstrating that mechanical input directly affects electrical output.
To fully characterise an AC source, we must specify at minimum: {{d3}} (how fast it oscillates), {{d4}} (how large the voltage swings), and the waveform shape (usually sinusoidal).
When doubling rotation speed, frequency doubles (T is {{d5}}) and amplitude doubles, meaning the peak-to-peak voltage becomes {{d6}} times the original.
